fields.doc: Color of the star as measured by the difference between b and y (Stromgren) bands

fields.doc: Color of the star as measured by the m1 (Stromgren) system

fields.doc: Color of the star as measured by the difference between V (Johnson) and R (Cousins) bands

fields.doc: Color of the star as measured by the c1 (Stromgren) system

fields.doc: Color of the star as measured by the difference between B and V (Johnson) bands

fields.doc: Color of the star as measured by the difference between V (Johnson) and I (Cousins) bands
Number of literature time series available for this star in the NASA Exoplanet Archive

fields.name: ValueAsymErrBlend
fields.doc: Length of a line segment from the center of the star to its surface, measured in units of radius of the Sun

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: Minimum mass of a planet as measured by radial velocity, measured in units of masses of Jupiter
Flag indicating whether the planet orbits a binary system
Flag indicating if the planet host star exhibits astrometrical variations due to the planet

fields.name: UTF8String
fields.doc: Link to the planet page in the Exoplanet Encyclopaedia

fields.name: UTF8String
fields.doc: Reference for publication used for default parameter

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: The angular separation between the ascending node of the orbit and the location in the orbit of periastron
Flag indicating if the planet host star exhibits radial velocity variations due to the planet

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: Insolation flux is another way to give the equilibrium temperature. It's given in units relative to those measured for the Earth from the Sun

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: The size of the relative flux decrement caused by the orbiting body transiting in front of the star

fields.name: UTF8String
fields.doc: Link to the planet page in Exoplanet Data Explorer

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: The equilibrium temperature of the planet as modeled by a black body heated only by its host star, or for directly imaged planets, the effective temperature of the planet required to match the measured luminosity if the planet were a black body

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: Amount of mass per unit of volume of the planet

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: The time given by the average of the time the planet begins to cross the stellar limb and the time the planet finishes crossing the stellar limb
Number of Notes associated with the planet. View all notes in the Confirmed Planet Overview page.

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: Depth of occultation of secondary eclipse

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: Time the planet takes to make a complete orbit around the host star or system

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: Half the peak-to-peak amplitude of variability in the stellar radial velocity

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: Angular distance of the orbital plane from the line of sight
Number of Stellar and Planet Parameters

fields.name: ValueAsymErrNoLim
fields.doc: The calculated angular separation (semi-major axis/distance) between the star and the planet. This value is only calculated for systems with both a semi-major axis and a distance value.

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: Amount by which the orbit of the planet deviates from a perfect circle
Publication Date of the planet discovery referee publication
Flag indicating if the planet transits its host star
Ratio of Planet to Stellar Radius Limit Flag
Ratio of Planet to Stellar Radius Lower Unc.
Ratio of Planet to Stellar Radius
Ratio of Planet to Stellar Radius Upper Unc.

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: The planet radius divided by the stellar radius

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: The time at which the orbiting body is at its closest approach to the star it orbits (i.e. is at periastron)
Flag indicating whether the planet exhibits orbital modulations on the phase curve

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: The length of time from the moment the planet begins to cross the stellar limb to the moment the planet finishes crossing the stellar limb

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: The longest diameter of an elliptic orbit, or for directly imaged planets, the projected separation in the plane of the sky

Flag indicating if the planet orbit exhibits transit timing variations from another planet in the system.

Note: Non-transiting planets discovered via the transit timing variations of another planet in the system will not have their TTV flag set, since they do not themselves demonstrate TTVs.
Flag indicating if the planetary system signature is present in data taken with the Kepler mission

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: The sky-projected distance between the center of the stellar disc and the center of the planet disc at conjunction, normalized by the stellar radius
Ratio of Distance to Stellar Radius Limit Flag
Ratio of Distance to Stellar Radius Lower Unc.
Ratio of Distance to Stellar Radius
Ratio of Distance to Stellar Radius Upper Unc.

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: The distance between the planet and the star at mid-transit divided by the stellar radius. For the case of zero orbital eccentricity, the distance at mid-transit is the semi-major axis of the planetary orbit.

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: Amount of matter contained in the planet, measured in units of masses of Jupiter
Flag indicating if the planet has been observed via imaging techniques

fields.name: ValueAsymErr
fields.doc: Length of a line segment from the center of the planet to its surface, measured in units of radius of Jupiter

fields.name: UTF8String
fields.doc: Name of instrument of planet discovery observations

fields.name: UTF8String
fields.doc: Name of telescope of planet discovery observations
Name of facility of planet discovery observations
Location of observation of planet discovery (Ground or Space)
Planet Mass or M*sin(i)Lower Unc. [Jupiter mass]
Planet Mass or M*sin(i)Upper Unc. [Jupiter mass]

fields.name: ValueAsymErrProvenance
fields.doc: Best planet mass measurement in units of masses of Jupiter. Either Mass, M*sin(i)/sin(i), or M*sin(i). See provenance for source of the measurement.
Flag indicating if the planetary system signature is present in data taken with the K2 Mission
